subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... Nothing could be simpler!  We say: Write the letter #28 Et for the vowel you use in words like dress , step , ebb , hem , pet , leg , shelf ,
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> > But we don't have to put up with "iksent" or "ayksunt" for "accent"
> > (instead of "aksent"), if we accept the principle that Et is used for
> > whatever sound functions in the writer's dialect the way short-e
> > functions in "mainstream" dialects.
>
> Sounds like a nice idea. How would you write the definition of Et such
> that beginners in all accents understand it?

Nothing could be simpler! We say:

Write the letter #28 Et for the vowel you use in words like
"dress", "step", "ebb", "hem", "pet", "leg", "shelf", "effort",
"threat", "bread", "ready", "any", and "friend". Note: if you
pronounce the words "pin" and "pen", and "Jim" and "gem", the
same, you will have to remember to use #28 Et in the words that
Orthodox writes with "e".

This method represents a given sound by a what dialectologists call a
"lexical set", a list of words that share whatever the appropriate sound
in the dialect may be. There is also a warning about a possible merger:
short-e and short-i are merged by U.S. Southerners before /m/ and /n/.
This way we don't have to get into IPA, or exactly how these words are
pronounced in different dialects.

There is a standardized list of these lexical sets: this one is called
DRESS. (Note the all-caps notation for lexical set names, as opposed
to upper/lower case for QS letter names.) The curious can look at the
explanation at http://www.everything2.com/index.pl?node_id=1674006 .
I'll just mention that my English merges these sets: LOT = PALM, TRAP =
BATH, THOUGHT = CLOTH, NORTH = FORCE, NURSE = UTTER. Fortunately for me,
QS has no separate letters for BATH or CLOTH or FORCE.

> If Elizabethan England functioned adequately with random spelling
> (QS is orderly within an accent)

Fair enough, but the U.S. has at least six or seven major accents
(and many local ones), Ireland has five, Australia three, and the
U.K. has dozens, depending on how you count.

> the Elizabethan lunatic orthodoxy produced a Shakespeare as you point out.

Well, not *produced*. His works *survived* it.

> I believe that constitutes an anecdote, not quite constituting
> compelling evidence of the majority's behavior. Are you saying that
> the *majority* of the *typical* person's family, friends and coworkers
> are in an accent remarkably different than theirs? I must disagree.

I really don't know. Most people in the U.S. live in cities, and it's
common in cities to meet people from different parts of the country
and other anglophone countries with different accents.

> I contend that, in practice at least, anyone anywhere would
> reproduce the example in the QM with a tiny number of letter changes.
> If you feel our friends in the antipodes would write QS radically
> differently, just point me to some downloadable Australian
> pronunciation dictionary I'll run it through my app so you can prove
> your point.

There are very few Australian dictionaries of any sort, never mind
freely available online ones, unfortunately. But you can see an
rough mapping between RP and General Australian at
http://www.ling.mq.edu.au/speech/phonetics/phonetics/ausenglish/auseng_vowels.html

--
John Cowan cowan@... http://ccil.org/~cowan
If I have seen farther than others, it is because I am surrounded by dwarves.
--Murray Gell-Mann
